Melia v. Zenner, 385 Mass. 153 (1982) (r.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case (Commonwealth v. Tavares), not Melia v. Accordingly, it cannot serve as authority for the stated landlord-tenant proposition.
Melia v. Zenner, 385 Mass. 153 (1982) (r.relevant_excerpt: The opinion throughout addresses issues of Miranda waiver, voluntariness of statements, reasonable doubt instructions, juror misconduct, and reduction of a murder conviction under G. L. c. 278, § 33E. There is no discussion of landlords, tenants, rental property, or covenants of quiet enjoyment in this text.

Cushing v. Lugo, 380 Mass. 494 (1980) (c.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a criminal appeal involving a murder conviction and evidentiary/hearsay issues. It does not concern landlord-tenant law, landlord obligations, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for legal principles about landlord responsibilities or quiet enjoyment.
Cushing v. Lugo, 380 Mass. 494 (1980) (c.relevant_excerpt: The defendant James K. Meech did not deny that he killed Edward Gerke in a Lowell rooming house in the early evening of January 7, 1978, but he put in issue his criminal responsibility at the time. A jury found him guilty of murder in the first degree, as well as assault and battery with a dangerous weapon. He brings his appeal... claiming that the judge erred in excluding the grand jury testimony of a witness who died before trial, and in permitting repeated references by prosecution witnesses to the defendant’s prior incarcerations.

Seavey v. Kravitz, 370 Mass. 261 (1976).raw_text: Seavey v. Kravitz, 370 Mass. 261 (1976) (discussing landlord obligations to protect tenants from third-party interference in certain circumstances).
Seavey v. Kravitz, 370 Mass. 261 (1976).proposition: (These authorities illustrate the legal principles applicable to landlord obligations and the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.)
Seavey v. Kravitz, 370 Mass. 261 (1976).support_reasoning: The provided opinion is Tritsch v. Boston Edison (a contribution/interest and judgment-calculation case), not Seavey v. Kravitz, and it concerns settlement credits, interest, and timing of judgment in a tort action involving joint tortfeasors. It does not discuss landlord–tenant law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or a landlord’s duty to protect tenants from third-party interference. Accordingly, this opinion does not support the proposition about landlord obligations and quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Seavey v. Kravitz, 370 Mass. 261 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In our earlier opinion we were concerned lest Tritsch receive ‘double’ payment — payment by Edison of the judgment based on the whole verdict, plus the settlement. We had no design to deprive Tritsch of a single full recovery. Had he been injured by a single tortfeasor and obtained a favorable judgment on March 19, 1973, a payment on account by the judgment debtor in April, 1974, would have been applied to reduce the balance outstanding on the judgment on that date. We do not perceive why the result should be different by reason of the fact that the partial payment came from another source.”

Gordon v. Dir. of the Div. of Health, 40.raw_text: Gordon v. Dir. of the Div. of Health, 401 Mass. 321 (1988) (public-health-related landlord obligations).
Gordon v. Dir. of the Div. of Health, 40.proposition: (These authorities illustrate the legal principles applicable to landlord obligations and the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.)
Gordon v. Dir. of the Div. of Health, 40.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal perjury case involving a police officer and evidence issues; it does not concern landlord–tenant law, landlord obligations, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. Nothing in the holding or reasoning discusses landlord duties, habitability, quiet enjoyment, or public‑health-related conditions in rental housing. Thus, it does not provide authority for the stated landlord-tenant proposition and appears to be mis-cited.
Gordon v. Dir. of the Div. of Health, 40.relevant_excerpt: Since the early 1800’s we have said that “one may not be convicted of perjury except on the directly opposing testimony of either two witnesses or one witness and, in addition, ‘independent evidence [of] strong corroborating circumstances. . . .’” Commonwealth v. Parker, 2 Cush. 212, 223-224 (1848). This so-called “quantitative rule” has been criticized strongly in recent years as inflexible and mechanical. Commonwealth v. Hawley, 380 Mass. 70, 81-82 (1980).

Lynch v. Bristol Industrial Trust, 32 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns arbitrators’ authority to award punitive damages under the Federal Arbitration Act, New York law, and NYSE rules. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, landlord obligations, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. Accordingly, it does not support the stated proposition about landlord obligations and the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Lynch v. Bristol Industrial Trust, 32 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The primary question to be decided is whether the Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) preempts State law so as to permit an arbitral award of punitive damages under an agreement purporting to be governed by New York law and providing that disputes are to be resolved by arbitration under the rules of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE).

Walker v. Waskiewicz, 37 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is Conway v. Smerling (or a related Conway case), dealing with malicious prosecution, tortious interference with advantageous business relations, and intentional infliction of emotional distress between an employer and former employee. It does not address landlord obligations, common areas, security, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law. Accordingly, this case does not support the stated proposition about landlord obligations and quiet enjoyment.
Walker v. Waskiewicz, 37 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Conway launched a four-barreled lawsuit involving claims of 1) defamation; 2) malicious prosecution; 3) tortious interference with advantageous business relationships; and 4) intentional infliction of emotional distress… Our task in review is to consider whether any evidence, considered in the light most favorable to the plaintiff…permits a reasonable inference in favor of the plaintiff on the three counts for which the jury returned favorable findings.”

Campagna v. Commonwealth, 20 Mass. App..raw_text: Campagna v. Commonwealth, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1985) (discussing landlord obligation with respect to safety and habitability).
Campagna v. Commonwealth, 20 Mass. App..proposition: (These authorities illustrate the legal principles applicable to landlord obligations and the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.)
Campagna v. Commonwealth, 20 Mass. App..support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal procedure case about dismissal of indictments for violation of the speedy trial rule (Mass. R. Crim. P. 36). It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, habitability, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Citing it for Massachusetts landlord obligations or quiet enjoyment principles is inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
Campagna v. Commonwealth, 20 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: Motion Judge No. 2 thus ruled that the time which elapsed after November 14, 1983, was not excludable. She ruled that the burden of assuring that criminal defendants receive a speedy trial rests upon the Commonwealth, which “has assumed strong control over the trial lists and the cases set down for trial.” See Barry v. Commonwealth, 390 Mass. 285, 296 n.13, second par. (1983). This conclusion is consistent with the specific interpretation found in the Reporters’ Notes to Mass.R.Crim.P. 36…
